reviewText: Low budget, bad acting, and preposterous plot.  Preposterous even for a zombie/living dead flick.  The government (sigh) develops a virus intended for use to make "super soldiers" (stop me if you've heard this before).  What's more, they decide to test it on a town in Maryland.  Like I said, preposterous.  For die-hard zombie fans only.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Deadlands 2: Trapped might be a Indie FilmBut, it's a Very Smart and a Carefully Filmed Indie FilmTaking Elements from Both Return of the Living Dead & Dawn of the Dead and the look and feel of ClerksYou have Deadlands IIDirector/Writer Gary Ugarek might just be the King of The New Indie Film WaveEverything about this  Small Film worksThe Actors are very good (Nothing seems to over the top)  I've seen some bad Low Budget Zombie Films (Children of the Living Dead come to mind)  This isn't one of themThe Soundtrack is a Throw-back that adds allot to the story and  pacing.The Story of Survivors being held up in a Movie Theater is Extremely Smart and I'm amazed the Idea hasn't been used up until Now!Unlike Major Studio Films Like Sony who Trashed a License like Resident Evil (And hide the Story behind Flawed Plot, Hot Models turned actress and Poor CGI F/X)  Deadlands 2 is true to the genre and doesn't play by the B.S. Hollywood RulesGreat Job Gary  keep on Filming!A True Must See Doomsday Zombie FilmDon't let the word Indie keep you away from this Fun Homage to all things Dead!  9.5/10
summary: My Review of the Limited Extended Unrated  BR  Disc

reviewText: the movie was made for 6 thousand dollars, spend two more and have a real ending, enjoyed the movie, the director/producer, gary, signed my copy for me when i bought it, i'm a zombie fan and liked it, but lacked a real ending which it really needed, glad i bought it for my collection, but don't expect resident evil or return of the living dead, will update this after i watch the movie again, for thats when i can really give a detailed review on it, but hated not showing a real ending.possible spoiler alert.the other big problem is how they went from one scene to another, for example, when the people in the car saw someone in the road fall down, they stop to help, next thing you know the guy got bitten and you don't see how, maybe they messed up the scene so just cut it, but the movie needed that scene, that happened about three times.i've seen bigger budget movies that i liked less then this movie, will keep it, even with the lousy no ending shown..
summary: good independant film with no real ending

reviewText: A group of people trapped in a movie theater while zombies try to brake in and put the chomp on them--holy Bava!  I smell a deja-vu.  Were this the only premise of the movie, it would be easy enough to write this whole venture off as shameless plagiarism.  What sets Deadlands 2 apart from Bava's "Demons" (but not necessarily above it, much less on equal terms) is Ugarek's penchant for imbuing his movies with the everyday and bland.  Put another way, his characters' respective encounters with social entropy (zombie attack), though mostly woodenly acted, are more realistic and believable than the knockouts you see (an Asia Argento lookalike in my neighborhood?  yeah right....)in the Resident Evil or even Romero's movies.  The soundtrack was an improvement.  Much of the music recalls the band, Goblin, when they were used for many of Argento and Fulcii's films in the late 70s and on into the 80s.  Although the setting of the movie theater after closing time and the idea of a government experiment (come on, it's a zombie movie--is this really any stretch of a teaser?) lasting throughout the night necessitate the dark settings, my biggest negative for this movie was that half of it was just plain difficult to see.  Still, the scenes are tight and the pacing is brisk.  Overall, an improvement over the first Deadlands, which in and of itself wasn't too bad.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Gary - I have to say, I dearly LOVED the first Deadlands you did.  Even with a lower budget, I watch that thing over and over.  It just srikes the nerve where I like it stuck, you know?  I waited and waited , then waited, for your sequal. To be honest I'm not that crazy about this one, even though it is obvious lots of work went into it and lots of plot development. The media used for filming is grainey and stark - almost like the lighting was not right, and the lense compensated by over grain pixelation or if was done in the final cut when you maybe tried to increase the visibility?  It just failed to have the "coming to get you Barbara" groove that the first one did. I hope you will take this in the manner it was intended and I hope this one does well enough that you look into keeping it up - but I would provide my opinion (as the one buying it with no idea of the hassles of actually MAKING a movie - so for what my thoughts are really worth) that if you do, you harken back to the things about the first Deadlands that made that such a winner of a first film.
Title: N/A
